### Challenge Overview 

The goal of the challenge is to factorize N knowing the way his factors has been generated.
We can see that the biggest number has at most `70 bits` which is pretty small and easy to factor even if the number of factors is big (`40` in this case).

In order to solve the challenge we can use `Pollard-Rho` or `Lenstra's ECM` 

In this case we are using `Lenstra's ECM` in sage , you can read about it [here](https://doc.sagemath.org/html/en/reference/interfaces/sage/interfaces/ecm.html).

### Solver Script

```python
from time import time
from Crypto.Util.number import long_to_bytes
from sympy import prod
from sage.all import *

N = 
c = 
e = 65537

start_time = time()

factors = ecm.factor(N)
print(factors)

phi = prod([(p-1) for p in factors])

d = pow(e, -1, phi)

m = pow(c, d, N)

print(long_to_bytes(m).decode())
```
